title: Tom Lynch best player in AFL, Dermott Brereton, Gold Coast Suns, Coleman Medal 2016 | Perth Now
text:
Hawthorn great Dermott Brereton says Gold Coast forward Tom Lynch is the best player in the AFL Tom Morris, FOX SPORTS February 21, 2017 11:16am 
HAWTHORN great Dermott Brereton believes Gold Coast co-captain Tom Lynch is the best player in the AFL. 
This is despite Champion Data rating the 24-year-old as the fifth best forward in the competition. 
But Brereton, who played in five flags for Hawthorn, believes the stats are skewed by the Suns poor 2016 in which they ranked 14th for inside 50s and won just six games. 
Indeed if he could select any player in the competition, Brereton wouldn’t pick Patrick Dangerfield, Nat Fyfe or even Lance Franklin. Lynch would be his man. 
“(Lynch) is the best player in the comp,” Brereton told SEN. 
“If you gave me an open chequebook and said start a club, who do you want to buy first? Tom Lynch is my number one target. Bar none … The best player at your club to build around, it is Tom Lynch.” 
KEY FORWARDS: ROUGHY THE FORWARD KING DESPITE HIS YEAR OUT 
Brereton is right about Lynch’s importance to the Suns. 
Rodney Eade’s team targeted the key forward with 36 per cent of kicks inside 50 last year, ranked No. 1 in the AFL. There was good reason for this, though. The ex-Dandenong Stingray took a competition-high 63 contested marks and finished third in the Coleman Medal. 
All this in a team that was missing its three best midfielders for the vast majority of the year. 
“Lynch is extraordinary,” he said. 
“He took the most contested marks last year in a team which was in the bottom four and they kicked it into the forward line like puff bags, they were hopeless. 
“He works the hardest out of every key forward, he has the best hands. He is a bit robotic in his kicking nature but he runs hard, works hard, he’s aggressive and just marks anything above head height in his area.” media_camera Tom Lynch. Photo: David Clark

Brereton also revealed he suffered an almost identical hip injury to Sun Sam Day’s. 
“That hip injury ruined my career … I never felt the same again,” he said. 
“Having said that, we’re talking 25 years ago so the technology as to how to treat this and how to repair it under surgery is through the roof. Mine was the first time they ever operated on that area for a footballer. 
“I’d feel confident that he’ll come back, but being a big hip injury that I’ve got first-hand experience of, I feel for the lad. I would say there is no hope of him coming back this year.”
